qas.question: What kind of drill bit do you need to drill holes in a PCB?
What kind of material sometimes used for drilling will lose sharpness quickly if used for PCBs?
What property do PCBs have that makes them tough to drill through?
What does the "NCD" in "NCD files" mean?
What's another name for NCD files that has an "x" in it?
Holes through a PBC are drilled how?

plausible_answers.text: so as not to mar or tear the traces

qas.question: Drill bits must remain dull why?

plausible_answers.text: since the drill bits will dull quickly and thus tear the copper and ruin the boards

qas.question: Drilling with high-speed-steel is feasible why?

plausible_answers.text: the location and size of each drilled hole

qas.question: Drilling must be low RPM and high feed to be what?

context: Holes through a PCB are typically drilled <b5_0>with small-diameter drill bits<b5_0/> made of solid <a0_0>coated tungsten carbide<a0_0/>. Coated tungsten carbide is recommended since many board materials are very <a2_0>abrasive<a2_0/> and drilling must be high RPM and high feed to be <b9_0>cost effective<b9_0/>. Drill bits must also remain sharp <b6_0>so as not to mar or tear the traces<b6_0/>. Drilling with <a1_0>high-speed-steel<a1_0/> is simply not feasible <b7_0>since the drill bits will dull quickly and thus tear the copper and ruin the boards<b7_0/>. The drilling is performed by automated drilling machines with placement controlled by a drill tape or drill file. These computer-generated files are also called <a3_0>numerically controlled drill<a3_0/> (NCD) files or "<a4_0>Excellon files<a4_0/>". The drill file describes <b8_0>the location and size of each drilled hole<b8_0/>.
